body.p:
The undersigned would respectfully State, That at the March Term ^1861^ of the Shelby circuit court, a verdict, upon Indictment, was rendered against Moses Washburn for $300. -- That an Execution was issued thereon which was respited, by your Excellency, for twelve months, upon the expiration of which time, execution was again issued and returned "no property found"; after which a Capias Profine was issued, by virtue of which the Sheriff arrested the said Washburn and lodged him in the gaol of the county, where he is now confined and has been for several days. In His former petition, to which referance is made, will be found the signatures of all his neighbors -- witnesses & if we mistake not that of the Commonwealths Attorney -- Washburn is a harmless, inoffensive old man, and to say nothing of the verdict, we regard the legal costs ofthe case and the Commonwealths Attorneys fee which together exceed $100 as of itself an excessive fine for the offence proven -- Your Respit, however, has been of incalculable advantage & benefit to said Washburn -- he now looks like a different man, bearing about him no evidences
of dissipated habits -- We, therefore msot earnestly hope and ask of your Excellency to remit the fine, viz, $210, thereof and release the poor old fellow from prison, for we believe, that he will go out a much better man and that the prosecution has resulted in great service to him --
All of which is respectfully submitted.

J M & W C Bullock Attys at Law
Wm A. Jones Clk. Circt Court
John T Ballard clk County Court
J L Caldwell Judge Shelby County Court
T O Shackelford Master in Chancery
J S Roberts Sheriff Shelby Co
J. T. Whitaker Police Judge S Ville
C M Stratton Jailor

Shelby Cir. Ct
$300. } Disorderly House
M. Washburn
